display_asset.caption: A survivor is carried out on a stretcher after spending more than 60 hours trapped following a landslide that engulfed dozens of buildings in Shenzhen, China.

summaries.body: A young migrant worker is rescued after 67 hours trapped inside a collapsed factory in Shenzhen, China.

display_asset.caption: NASA's Mars InSight lander spacecraft, at Lockheed Martin near Denver in April, will miss its March 2016 launch date.

summaries.body: NASA’s next Mars mission will have to wait at least two years because of leaks in an instrument, officials said.
A member of British Parliament demanded to know why the U.S. refused to let a Muslim family fly to Disneyland.

display_asset.caption: Tuesday was a warm and wet day in Manhattan.

summaries.body: “We’re living through history, and not of a good kind,” a climate activist said, as a steamy Christmas caps off what's likely to be the world's hottest year on record.
Ahead of the holiday, Santa Claus or his doppelgängers are spotted in helicopters, surfing and swimming with sharks.
After a drone flying with a camera nearly hit a skier on Tuesday, the sport's governing body banned the devices from World Cup events.
Kim Dotcom, founder of the file-sharing website Megaupload, can be extradited to the United States, a New Zealand judge ruled on Wednesday.

display_asset.caption: Robert A. Durst during a court appearance in New York in 2014.

summaries.body: Robert A. Durst, who is accused of killing a friend in 2000, has agreed to be extradited to Los Angeles from Louisiana by mid-August to face a murder charge.
A wild sea otter swam into an open pool at the Monterey Bay Aquarium in California to give birth last weekend.
Ursula Gauthier, a French reporter, says China may expel her for an article she wrote criticizing the country's treatment of the Uighur minority.
Thailand’s prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, released a new tune for the country’s citizens, his second since taking power in 2014.

display_asset.caption: From left, Martin Shkreli, who ran drug companies; Lynn Tilton, a private equity executive; and Charlie Shrem, ex-chief of a money transfer service.
display_asset.credit: From left: Craig Ruttle/Associated Press; Robert F. Bukaty/Associated Press; Adrees Latif/Reuters

summaries.body: Executives charged with wrongdoing used to defer to their lawyers. But now they are turning to social media -- in a legally risky move -- to proclaim their innocence.

display_asset.caption: President Obama signing the repeal of the military's "don't ask, don't tell" policy in Washington on Dec. 22, 2010.
display_asset.credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times

summaries.body: Five years after the military's “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy was repealed, President Obama promised on Facebook to continue fighting against prejudice.

display_asset.caption: Demonstrators filled the Mall of America rotunda and chanted “Black lives matter” to protest police brutality, on Dec. 12, 2014, in Bloomington, Minn.
display_asset.credit: Aaron Lavinsky/The Star Tribune, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A judge in Minnesota barred some Black Lives Matter activists from a planned protest at the Mall of America on Wednesday, but the group said it would still demonstrate.

display_asset.caption: Investigators checked the car they believed was involved in the crash on the Las Vegas Strip on Sunday.
display_asset.credit: Steve Marcus/Las Vegas Sun, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Once praised as a role model, Lakeisha Holloway, the motorist accused of crashing into pedestrians in Las Vegas, had fallen on hard times.

display_asset.caption: Shaima Qassem Abdelrahman, the newly crowned Miss Iraq.

summaries.body: A new Miss Iraq was crowned in Baghdad for the first time since 1972 in a contest that faced fierce conservative opposition as well as reported death threats.

display_asset.caption: A rhino that was killed for its horn at Kruger National Park in South Africa in February. The country, which has 80 percent of the world’s rhino population, has been hit particularly hard by illegal poaching, and officials there are trying to crack down on the trade.

summaries.body: The U.S. is spending millions to fight wildlife poaching, which has decimated elephant and rhino populations in Africa, while fueling the growth of international gangs.
The authorities in Texas named the mother of Ethan Couch, who has become known as the "affluenza teen," as a missing person as they intensify their hunt for him.

display_asset.caption: Nicolas Cage returned the skull of a Tyrannosaurus bataar that had been stolen from Mongolia.
display_asset.credit: Michael Lewis for The New York Times

summaries.body: A dinosaur skull owned by Nicolas Cage, star of the "National Treasure" franchise, turned out to be stolen from Mongolia. He's returning it.
CBGB, the famed New York City rock club that closed a decade ago, is reopening as a restaurant in Newark Liberty International Airport.

display_asset.caption: Beijing on Monday, the third day of a four-day red alert for hazardous air pollution.

summaries.body: Companies in southern China have been advertising the attractions of their sun-filled, tree-lined cities in a bid to lure people from smoggy Beijing.
A $1.5 million grant from New York State will pay for a memorial to the Triangle fire of 1911 in which 146 garment workers died.
The Navy has no plans to alter its fitness requirements for SEAL members next year, when women will be able to join the units.
Muslim passengers on a bus in Kenya defied Shabab militants seeking to target Christians by refusing to split into groups.
In Turkmenistan, it is now illegal to change the name of a purebred horse during its lifetime.

display_asset.caption: A Chipotle in San Francisco. The latest outbreak was tied to two outlets in Kansas and Oklahoma.

summaries.body: Five more people became sick with E. coli after eating at two Chipotle restaurants in Kansas and Oklahoma.

display_asset.caption: Lawmakers left the Capitol in Washington on Friday for their holiday recess.

summaries.body: Deficits no longer appear to matter, and Democrats and Republicans can indeed work together. Here are the most memorable moments from Congress in 2015.

display_asset.caption: The Memorial Arch in Tappan Square at Oberlin College.
display_asset.credit: Dustin Franz for The New York Times

summaries.body: Some students at Oberlin College are accusing its cafeteria of cultural appropriation: The culprits include a Chinese chicken dish and poorly prepared sushi.

display_asset.caption: Chelsea Clinton and her husband Marc Mezvinsky.

summaries.body: Chelsea Clinton announced that she's expecting a second baby with her husband, Marc Mezvinsky. “Charlotte is going to be a big sister!” she wrote on Twitter.

display_asset.caption: Side judge Michael Banks had to separate the Panthers' Josh Norman and the Giants' Odell Beckham Jr. after the two scuffled in the second half.

summaries.body: Odell Beckham Jr., the Giants’ sensational receiver, has been suspended for one game after repeatedly getting tangled with Panthers cornerback Josh Norman on Sunday.
